I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the 2003 Country Programming Mission for the People's Republic of China (PRC), 
the Government confirmed its request for technical assistance (TA) to prepare an integrated roads 
development project  (the Project)  in central Sichuan Province.1 The Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC in October 2003; traveled to the project area; carried 
out an initial poverty and social assessment (IPSA) and rapid environmental assessment (REA); 
and discussed economic, social development,  and project-specific issues with officials of the 
central and local governments. This report is based on the understanding reached with the 
Government  on  the  objectives,  scope,  costs,  terms  of  reference,  and  implementation 
arrangements for the TA, and the Mission's observations in the field. The TA framework, outlining 
the goal, purpose, outputs, and inputs, is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC's rapid economic growth over the last decade has substantially increased the 
demand  for  transport  services.  The  changing  structure  and  increasing  sophistication  of  the 
economy have altered the pattern of transport demand, with rapid growth in the demand for road 
transport compared with other modes. Road traffic grew at 9.4% per annum for passenger traffic, 
reaching 781 billion passenger-kilometers (km), and 6.1% per annum for freight, reaching 678 
billion ton-km in 2002. The continued development of the private sector and light manufacturing 
industries, expansion of the service sector, increasing volumes of intra- and interprovincial trade, 
and rapidly growing demand for passenger travel favor the development of flexible, efficient, and 
market-responsive road transport services. Car ownership is growing rapidly, and an increasing 
proportion of passengers are traveling by road. The PRC’s road network grew from 1.16 million 
km in 1995 to 1.76 million km in 2002, equivalent to an annual increase of 85,700 km. Of this, the 
expressway length increased from 2,141 km to 25,200 km during the same period. 2 However, the 
road network is still underdeveloped in quality and extent. High standard roads, i.e., above class 
II,3 account for only about 14% of the total road network; the remaining 86% (class III road and 
below) are medium- to low-grade paved and gravel roads. With only 1,285 km of roads per million 
inhabitants and  18.3 km per 100 km2 in 2002, the density of the PRC's road network is low, 
resulting in serious transport capacity constraints and bottlenecks. 
 
3.  In Sichuan Province, road traffic grew at a slower pace than the national average: 6.5% 
per annum for passenger traffic, reaching 45 billion passenger-km, and 3.4% per annum for 
freight traffic, reaching 24 billion ton-km. Road traffic accounts for  about two thirds  of total 
passenger traffic and  one third of total freight traffic. The road network  in Sichuan remains 
underdeveloped. The total road length was 111,898 km in 2002, including 1,501 km expressway. 
High standard roads, i.e., above class II, were 11,593 km, accounting for only about 10% of the 
total road network, and the remaining  90% are class III roads. With only 1,320 km of roads per 
million inhabitants and 23.1 km of road per 100 square kilometers of land, the density of the 
Sichuan Province’s road network is low. By 2005, the total road length is expected to reach 
116,000 km (including 1,700 km of expressways and 14,000 km of class II and above roads). In 
addition, 4,500 km of county roads extending to poor remote areas will be completed.

4.  The link between road development and poverty reduction is supported by studies and 
the evaluation of several completed road projects financed by ADB4 and the World Bank.5 
Preliminary findings of an ongoing TA6 have confirmed that the contribution of road investments 
to economic growth and poverty reduction in the PRC as well as the validity of the geographic 
focus of the road portfolio on the poorer western interior province.  They also revealed that 
complimentary  investments  in  local  roads  would  strengthen  the  impact  of  expressway 
investments and that well-integrated road investments help ensure that the benefits derived 
from the expressway filter down to the poor. A detailed case study in Shaanxi also found that 
improved roads were correlated with poverty reduction.7 Several studies and feedback from 
consultation with the poor have found that adequate transport infrastructure is a prerequisite for 
reducing poverty, and involving the participation of local communities increase the likelihood of 
success of road projects. Benefits for poor rural areas include lower transport costs; lower cost 
of inputs, expanded agricultural support services; improved farming practices; greater access to 
employment opportunities in urban areas; and better access to health, education, and social 
services.8  A prominent feature of the PRC’s poverty reduction strategy since the mid-1980s has 
been to accelerate investment in rural infrastructure. Investment in rural roads, for example, 
grew by 23% annually in the 1990s—more than double the annual growth in the 1980s.9 
 
5.  The Government’s policy for the road sector, as reflected in its Tenth Five Year Plan 
(2001–2005), calls for (i) accelerating the construction of the network of highways and national 
roads, with focus on five north-south and seven east-west sections of the national trunk highway 
system; (ii) commencing construction of eight new highways in the western region (total 18,000 
km); and (iii) by 2005, having approximately 1.95 million km of highways open to traffic, with 
expressways accounting for 35,000 km. In 2003, the Government announced plans for 5,300 
rural road projects with a total length of 78,000 km. A total of 176,000 km of rural roads will be 
built in the following 3 years, with an investment of $6 billion (CNY50 billion) provided by the 
central Government. Currently, 184 towns and 54,000 villages have no access to roads, most of 
which are in the western region. The plan is to develop road network that will reach 99.8% of 
towns and 96.0% of villages by 2005. By the end of 2010, all towns and villages will be 
connected to roads. This major program will be a pro-poor initiative since in many surveys the 
poor ranked improved roads as one of their highest development priorities. The Government’s 
commitment to reducing poverty through transport infrastructure investment is reflected in the 
poverty partnership agreement between the Government and ADB. 
 
6.  The private sector will be the PRC’s engine of employment generation and a main 
mechanism to increase productivity—two essential instruments to reduce poverty. According to 
the ADB surveys,10 infrastructure constraints are among the impediments faced by private

companies operating in the PRC. Of 756 domestic private firms interviewed, 21% cited poor 
roads as a major constraint after a lack of land and buildings. Among foreign firms, 39% would 
not expand their operations into the central and western provinces and infrastructure constraints 
were  one  of  the  barriers  most  frequently  cited.  It  is  imperative  that  road  infrastructure  be 
improved to attract private investment to the poor interior provinces. 
 
7.  Sichuan is a poor interior province located in the southwest PRC. With an area of 487,600 
square kilometers and population of 84.7 million, Sichuan is one of the largest and most populous 
provinces of the PRC. Sichuan’s gross domestic product per capita was $697 (CNY5,766) in 
2002, 71% of the national average, and per capita rural income was $255 (CNY2,108), 85% of the 
national average.  About one third of the counties in Sichuan  are officially designated poor 
counties. About 3 million people live below a rural per capita income of $76 (CNY625). One of the 
reasons  for  relatively  high  poverty  incidence  is  slow  economic  growth,  partly  because  of 
inadequate infrastructure  despite the  considerable investments. The bottlenecks in the road 
network hamper efficient transport access to large parts of the country. Better transport links are 
necessary to improve economic efficiency, foster domestic and international trade, facilitate 
interregional integration, and reduce poverty. 
 
8.  In Sichuan Province, significant road sector development is being implemented during 
the Tenth Five-Year Plan (2001–2005). Because of the need to remove transport bottlenecks to 
facilitate efficient, sustained economic growth and reduce poverty, Sichuan Province is investing 
$8.0 billion (CNY67 billion) during the Tenth Five Year Plan, up from $2.8 billion (CNY23 billion), 
during the  Ninth Five-Year Plan (1996–2000). The road sector investment  is growing  at an 
average annual rate of 13% during this period. The Government will have difficulty sustaining this 
level of investment even with official development assistance. 
 
9.  A proposed Project constitutes a 244-km access controlled four-lane expressway that will 
start 140 km southwest of Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, and extend southward to 
Lugu. The expressway forms part of the main 900-km north-south route connecting Chengdu and 
Kunming, the capital of Yunnan Province and is part of eight western corridors included in the 
Government’s Western Region Development Strategy. The expressway will traverse one district 
(Yuchen  in  Ya’an  City)  and  four  counties  (Yingjing,  Hanyuan,  Mianning,  and Shimian in 
Liangshan Yi Minority Autonomous Prefecture). The Project area will cover 12,288 km2 and a 
population in 2002 of 1.3 million, of which 1.0 million are rural (80%). The per capita gross 
domestic product in this area, $764 (CNY6,324), is lower than the national average $989 
(CNY8,184). The average  rural income is $260 (CNY2,150) per capita. The number of rural 
residents with an annual income below $121 (CNY1,000) is 237,214 (24% of the population). 
The four counties are all provincial level poverty counties. The severe socioeconomic conditions 
in this area were verified during the field investigation. 
 
10.  The Project is  the third road project in Sichuan for ADB financing. The first one, the 
Chengdu-Nanchong Expressway Project,11 was successfully opened to traffic in December 2003, 
and  was  awarded  a  national  prize  by  the  Ministry  of  Communications  as  a  high  quality 
expressway project. It contributed to poverty reduction by integrating expressway development 
with local road network improvement. Construction is starting on the Southern Sichuan Roads 
Development Project.12 The proposed project expressway will link up with the second project in 
Lugu. Lessons learned from the ongoing ADB-financed projects in Sichuan will be reviewed under 
the TA and incorporated in the project design. To ensure the distribution of benefits to the less

4 
developed communities, the TA will study the local road network and identify local roads in the 
Project area that could be included in the project scope. As the project expressway will be in 
mountainous terrain at  500–1,500 meters above sea level, and involve extensive tunnels and 
bridges accounting for 39% of the total length, the TA will carefully review design and construction 
methods  to  address  this  technical challenge.  Traffic on the  existing  330-km  road,  National 
Highway 108, is 763–4,409 vehicles per day (in medium truck units), depending on road sections 
and has been growing at about 10% per annum in the last 5 years.  
 
11.  ADB's  operational  strategy 13  in  the  PRC’s  road  sector  is  designed  to  remove 
infrastructure constraints and support policy and institutional reforms.  Since 1991, ADB has 
provided 27 loans totaling $4.8 billion to finance 3,555 km of highway development. The broad 
scope of these projects has included improving 5,826 km of local roads. Local roads have been 
included in the project scopes since 1995 to make ADB's road projects more pro-poor. All the 
ADB  loans  are  generally  being  implemented  satisfactorily.14 With  the  completion  of  the 
northeast transport corridor, the focus of ADB's activities in the road sector has shifted to poorer 
provinces in the western and central regions. The strategy supports (i) constructing roads that 
connect major growth centers and improve access in the western and central regions; (ii) 
integrating the national trunk highway system with local roads networks, particularly those that 
provide access to poor areas; (iii) promoting road safety and vehicle emission reductions; (iv) 
strengthening  the  corporatization  and  commercialization  of  expressway  organizations;  (v) 
adopting appropriate pricing policies to ensure optimum use of road transport capacity; and (vi) 
using alternative methods of investment financing, including private sector participation. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The TA will (i) assist  the Sichuan Provincial Communications Department (SPCD) in 
upgrading the feasibility study, including environmental impact assessment (EIA) and resettlement 
plan for the proposed  Central Sichuan Roads Development  Project in conformity with ADB’s 
requirements; and (ii) review the road sector issues and provide the basis for strengthening the 
ongoing policy dialogue with the Government in the key areas, focusing on the poverty impact of 
road  projects,  road  safety,  vehicle  emissions,  commercialization  and  corporatization,  private 
sector development, pricing policies for road users, and public transport services. The output will 
be a project suitable for ADB financing. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Government preparation for the Project has reached an advanced stage. The feasibility 
study and the EIA have been prepared and a resettlement plan will be prepared soon. The IPSA 
(Appendix 2) and REA (Appendix 2) carried out during fact-finding helped identify the social and 
environmental issues that need to be  addressed during project preparation. They also reviewed 
the need for assessing the social  and environmental aspects for which ADB has established 
policies and norms of good practice. The  IPSA examined  poverty conditions, minority issues, 
resettlement effects, gender issues,  and vulnerable groups, and concluded that  the key social 
issues to be assessed during project preparation are poverty impact, resettlement effects, and 
minority people. The REA concluded that the Project should be a category A project, requiring a 
                                                 
13 ADB. 2003. Country Strategy and Program (2004-2006): People’s Republic of China. Manila. 
14 The project completion reports of road projects concluded that nine projects were generally successful and one 
was partly successful. The project performance audit reports for four road projects concluded that the projects were 
either highly successful or successful.

5 
full EIA to be prepared. The TA will examine the available project documents,15 and prepare a 
project that is feasible from the technical, economic, and financial points of view and is in 
compliance with ADB’s safeguard policies on environment, resettlement, and indigenous people. 
The key activities will include field surveys; document review; data analysis; and discussion with 
stakeholders, including government officials, project beneficiaries, and affected people. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $880,000 equivalent, which consists of $490,000 in 
foreign exchange cost and $390,000 equivalent in local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $700,000 equivalent covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$210,000 equivalent of local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. The Government will finance the balance of the local currency cost, equivalent 
to $180,000, through the provision of counterpart staff, office facilities, and other support services. 
Detailed cost estimates are  provided in Appendix  3. The Government has been advised that 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  A team from an international consulting firm in association with domestic consultants will 
be engaged by ADB using the simplified technical proposal procedures in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other  arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
selection and engagement of domestic consultants. The TA will require about 17 person-months 
of international consulting services and 23 person-months of domestic consulting services to carry 
out the study as defined in the terms of reference (Appendix 4). The international consultants will 
have expertise in (i) highway engineering, (ii) transport economics, (iii) financial analysis and 
expressway operation, (iv) environmental analysis,   (v) poverty and social analysis, and (vi) 
resettlement. The international consultants will be encouraged to utilize domestic consultants in 
the above fields.  
 
16.  SPCD, as the Executing Agency for the TA, will appoint suitable counterpart staff who will 
be responsible for supervision and coordination of TA activities, including monitoring of progress, 
resolving any issues that may arise during implementation, assisting in arranging meetings, and 
liaising  with  government  agencies  and  organizations.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  will  ensure 
coordination  among  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  Ministry  of 
Communications, State Environmental Protection Administration, SPCD, and other government 
offices relevant to the TA. The consultants are expected to be fielded by mid-May 2004, and carry 
out their work for 5 months. The TA is expected to be completed in mid-October 2004. Workshops 
involving the Government, ADB,  and the consultants will be held in the PRC to review the 
consultant’s reports.  The  equipment  to  be  provided  under  the  TA  will  be  procured  by  the 
consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000, on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Central Sichuan Roads 
Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the People’s Republic of China: The 
transport sector contributes to poverty reduction directly through improved access to markets, 
employment  opportunities,  and  social  services,  and  indirectly  by  stimulating  economic 
development. Despite good natural resources, the project area has lagged behind in terms of 
economic development mainly due to lack of good transportation, which is currently limited to a 
class II or III highway. The Project will link the project area to the existing Chengdu-Ya’an 
expressway and the Xichang-Panzhihua expressway that is currently under construction with 
Asian Development Bank funding. The proposed Ya’an-Lugu expressway will reduce travel time 
and cost for passenger trips and freight transport, thereby facilitating economic and tourism 
development, job creation, and improved access to social services.    
 
 
2.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Classification: Other 
 
The  Project  will  directly  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  in  the  project  area  by  generating 
construction employment opportunities in the short term and improving access to market for cash 
crops.  The  Project  will  substantially  improve  transport  infrastructure  that  will  facilitate 
development mineral and tourism resources and thereby indirectly provide greater employment 
and income generation opportunities for local people.   
 
Further, the Project will improve access to social services in the county centers and larger cities. 
The  local  people  have  inconvenient  transportation  and  very  basic  education  and  medical 
facilities. The poverty incidence in the project area is estimated to be (i) 71,400 people, or 7%, 
based on the national poverty line of $76 (CNY625) income; and (ii) 237,214, or 24%, based on 
the provincial poverty line of $121 (CNY1,000) income. 
 
A detailed poverty analysis will be carried out to identify the causes of poverty in the project area 
and demonstrate how the Project will help reduce poverty by incorporating specific measures in 
the project scope. The analysis will be based on the Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis 
and Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects. 
 
 
3.  Participation Process 
 
Stakeholder analysis: Some public consultation has been carried  out  by  the  Executing Agency

environmental impact assessment. Further consultation will be carried out during the technical 
assistance (TA) to enhance the environmental management plan, conduct social surveys of 
affected people and ethnic minorities, and prepare the resettlement plan. This will be included in

Participatory strategy required:  In order to enhance benefits to the poor and particularly ethnic 
minorities, a participation strategy will need to be developed under the TA. This may focus on 
local roads and/or other rural development support. 
 
 
4.  Gender Issues 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: Expressway projects tend to be gender neutral, since 
the benefits accrue at the household level. In this remote area, employment of women for 
construction work is limited and constrained by the need for women to handle household work 
and animal husbandry. The TA will investigate opportunities to enhance the benefits to women 
(e.g., through adult education and skills training in cash crops, animal husbandry, tourism). 
Particular focus will be placed on ethnic minority women, as they tend to drop out of school and 
have limited skills for outside work.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Highway Engineering  
 
1.  Review all technical aspects presented in the feasibility study and available engineering 
designs. In view of the difficult topography in the project area, a thorough technical review is 
required, including (i) horizontal and vertical alignment; (ii) subsurface investigation, particularly 
where tunnels are proposed; (iii) availability and quality of local construction materials, (iv) 
pavement, bridge, and tunnel design options; (v) drainage facilities and culverts; (vi) siting and 
configuration of interchanges, toll stations, and service areas; (vii) provision for cross expressway 
access; and (viii) road safety features. Based on traffic volumes, forecast traffic, traffic mix, and 
axle loads, review the adequacy of the road capacity and pavement design, and  recommend 
measures to prevent overloading, such as installing vehicle weighing stations at selected entry 
points and other measures. 
 
2.  In collaboration with the economist and social and poverty specialist, prepare an inventory 
of the nonexpressway roads in the project area and propose substantial nonexpressway roads 
that should be included in the Project based upon established criteria, including consideration of 
the road network, poverty incidence, socioeconomic profile, and minority counties and townships. 
 
3.  Review  bills  of  quantities,  unit  prices,  and  costs  of  (i)  civil  works  for  expressway 
construction and local road improvement, and (ii) equipment and other facilities to be procured 
under the Project.  Review the proposed contract packaging and recommend the appropriate 
number and scope of contract packages for civil works and equipment for international competitive 
bidding contracts in accordance with the Guidelines for Procurement  of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB). Review and update the project cost estimates and indicate the foreign exchange 
(direct and indirect) and local currency costs, with due consideration given to the actual costs of 
recently awarded contracts of a similar nature in Sichuan. 
 
4.  Review the current road maintenance operation and management systems. Recommend 
suitable road maintenance systems and necessary equipment. Estimate the costs of routine and 
periodic maintenance for the expressway and local road components. 
 
5.  Prepare a project implementation schedule and a corresponding disbursement schedule 
covering  all  project  components,  including  (i)  expressway  construction  and  a  local  road 
development  program,  (ii)  procurement  and  commissioning  of  equipment,  and  (iii)  consulting 
services  for  construction  supervision.  Review  construction  supervision  requirements,  and 
recommend appropriate international and domestic supervision consultants’ inputs and estimate 
the associated costs.  
 
6.  Review the road safety monitoring system, the latest accident statistics in Sichuan and the 
project area and the new Traffic Safety Law. Design a road safety component including measures 
suitable to comply with the Road Traffic Safety Law. 
 
B.  Transport Economics 
 
7.  Review the current status and future plans (tenth  and eleventh 5-year plans) of road 
development in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Sichuan Province, including the project 
area (maps will be prepared for this purpose). Identify the role of the Project in the framework of the 
Western Region Development Strategy in supporting pro-poor growth and poverty reduction in the 
western part of the PRC in general and Sichuan Province in particular.

14 Appendix 4 
8.  Review existing traffic counts and origin-destination surveys, and obtain any additional 
necessary information on the present pattern of traffic by vehicle type and mode in the zone of 
influence of the Project. Prepare detailed traffic forecasts of the expressway and local roads for 
each vehicle type. Estimate average annual daily traffic at a range of toll rates taking into account 
traffic diversion from other transport modes and  long term gross domestic product and other 
economic indicators.  
 
9.  Review vehicle operating costs (VOC) information by vehicle type, calculate VOCs for the 
existing and proposed road networks, and quantify the benefits using appropriate shadow prices. 
Assess the extent of the benefits that will be passed onto transport users from reduced VOCs 
through lowered passenger fares and freight charges. 
 
10.  Assess the provision of trucking and public transport services focusing on the cities in the 
project  area  in  term  of  pricing  and  quality  and  frequency  of  service.  Assess  the  degree  of 
competition and the proportion of the reduced transport costs that are likely to be passed onto end 
users. Recommend ways to incorporate a public transport component to enhance project benefits 
for local residents. 
 
11.  Undertake economic evaluation in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Economic Analysis 
of Projects, by comparing the with- and without-project cases. Least cost analysis will also be 
carried out by evaluating alternative transport modes, designs, and alignments. Calculate the net 
present value and the economic internal rate of return for the expressway and the local road 
components and for the Project as a whole. Undertake sensitivity analysis by appropriately varying 
benefits, costs, implementation period, traffic diversion, generated traffic, and a combination of 
these factors. Indicate the toll levels for which the economic internal rate of return falls under the 
cutoff rate of 12%. Calculate switching values and compare with those for existing expressway 
projects. Carry out quantitative risk analysis by considering the possible values for key variables, 
and the probability that they may occur. Recommend ways by which project risks can be reduced. 
 
12.  With the assistance of the social and poverty specialist, carry out distribution analysis of 
project benefits, calculate the poverty impact ratio, and undertake a cause-and-effect analysis, 
following  the  methodology  set  forth  in  ADB's  Handbook  for  Integrating  Poverty  Impact 
Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects.  
 
13.  In collaboration with other relevant specialists, prepare a project framework  in an  ADB 
format,  including monitoring  indicators  that  will  be  used  to  assess  project  performance,  and 
baseline  and  target  values  for  the  selected  indicators,  covering  economic,  transport, 
socioeconomic, poverty impact, environmental, and resettlement aspects. 
 
C.  Financial Analysis and Expressway Operations 
 
14.  Review and update the proposed financing plan of the Project including the share of the 
ADB, the Ministry of Communications, Sichuan Province, domestic banks, and other sources, as 
appropriate.  Calculate  a  discounted  return  to  equity  over  the  project  life,  and  assess  its 
attractiveness to private investment. Review project cost estimates and drawdown schedules; and 
compute  price  contingencies  and  interest  and  other  financing  charges  during  construction  in 
accordance with Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects 
Financed by the Asian Development Bank.

expressway operation, including balance sheets, income statements, and cash flow statements in 
nominal terms.  
 
16.  In collaboration with the transport economist, determine and justify appropriate toll rates by 
vehicle type. Carry out financial evaluation by calculating the financial internal rate of return, using 
proposed toll rates and comparing it with a weighted average cost of capital. Undertake sensitivity 
tests by appropriately varying toll rates, project costs, implementation period, overall projected 
traffic volume, traffic diversion, change in the exchange rate, and a combination of these factors.  
 
17.  Undertake  the  financial  assessment  of  the  operating  entity,  including  (i)  corporate

covenants  to  monitor  financial  conditionalities  of  the  Project.  In  light  of  ADB’s  Policy  on 
Governance: Sound Development Management (1995), recommend ways to improve corporate 
governance  of  the  expressway  operating  entity,  e.g.,  through  entering  into  a  concession

the past decade. Examine the role of the road sector in the fiscal position of the province and 
analyze how the sector contributes to poverty reduction. 
 
20.  Review the current status of private sector participation in expressway development and 
operations in Sichuan Province (e.g., Sichuan Highway, Chengdu-Mianyang expressway) and the

concession by the private sector. Identify appropriate arrangements to implement such a strategy,

be used to finance local roads.

unemployment, education levels, health conditions, and other relevant socioeconomic data. The 
information should be separated by gender and ethnic group. These data and profiles should be 
sufficiently comprehensive to serve as the baseline for socioeconomic benefit monitoring.
